questions.question_text: A small business owner purchased an MFP and would like customers to be able to print from their mobile devices. However, customers should not be granted access to the wireless network. Which of the following should the business owner enable? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: EF
NFC isn't stated in the official study guide as the protocol for wireless printing. AirPrint utilises a wireless network, so access must be granted. The only options left are USB and Bluetooth. The question doesn't state anything about not using a 'wireless connection'. It only says about the wireless network. Another keyword is 'granted access', which clearly states about the company's wireless network, not the wireless connection.

It think because they say without wireless we must eliminate Airprint, NFC and Bluetooth. Parallel, Serial and USB are wired. Serial is not used on mobile devices like laptops, tablets and phones. USB is the newer wired connection for printers and new laptops and tablets/phones use USB to make connections, so USB is one answer. Parallel could be the other answer because older laptops might have this connection or if we used a USB to Parallel adapter it could work maybe. That is my reasoning for the answer in terms of not using wireless.
The answer is definitely NFC and BT. You need to connect to wifi to use air print and like JE39 said the rest just aren't viable options

comments.content: Exactly . Airprint use WIFI and it states without a network. So the only possible answers is NFC and bluetooth. Serial,USB, and parralel are all wires so it doesn't make to choice any of them
But It didn't state the printer support bt neither NFC but most phones support USB and parallel

discussion.content: I have printer can join with bluetooth and usb cable via phone

The answers should be NFC and Bluetooth, in my opinion. The reason being, the question says they should not have access to the network. With Airprint, you will have to access the printer through the local area network. The other options aren't available with phones. The only two that are available with phones and won't give you access to the network are NFC and BT. They are both considered PAN.

comments.content: Could be, i'd have gone with AirPrint and bluetooth

discussion.content: answer is wrong...i would go with airprint and nfc

Selected Answer: C
The Android or iOS software then uses the accelerometer's data to tell how you're holding your phone and orients the screen appropriately so that when you want to switch from browsing the web to watching a wide-screen video, the screen rotates automatically.
So C is the best option...
out of all these, C is the most likely the one Comptia is looking for. C is just less wrong than the rest in MHO.

comments.content: Frequently incorrect whenever the user tries to turn it to a different orientation I guess?

discussion.content: How can it be C? It mentions that frequently is incorrect. If it was locked it would be constantly at a particular orientation.

choices.D: The tablet needs a new inverter.
choices.B: The tablet needs a new screen protector.

questions.question_text: A user's touch-screen tablet is having issues with the screen orientation frequently being incorrect. Which of the following is MOST likely causing the issue?

A customer travels often and needs to connect a laptop to the home office server. The customer wants to use a cell phone data connection but has connected to the wrong network in the past. Which of the following would work BEST to ensure a secure connection through the cell phone?

discussion.content: Hotspot is no good solution, he can use the wrong WLAN. But Teathering with a USB-Cable: He will always connect with the right device: with his Smartphone!

comments.content:
I don't think so, using USB tethering is faster and more secure.
source:https://nectmodem.com/usb-tethering-vs-mobile-hotspot-which-is-better/
Not to mention using a tether to your device makes it impossible to connect to the wrong network.

questions.question_text: A technician has assembled an ITX system with a modern processor, but the machine does not POST. The processor fan spins up, and the LEDs on the motherboard light up, but no beeps are emitted by the system. Which of the following is the MOST likely cause of this issue?

choices.B: An incompatible memory type is installed.
choices.D: A faulty hard drive is installed.
choices.A: An incompatible NVMe SSD is installed.
choices.C: The wrong generation CPU is installed.

discussion.content:
Definitely the wrong answer. A PC will post with a faulty hard drive and with no hard drive.

Incompatible Ram is strange phrasing. Ram can be incompatible physically and electronically. If it's incompatible physically it isn't going to even be on the motherboard. If it's incompatible electronically it will most likely post but not be at the right frequency or be at a lower clock speed. It is unlikely that it would not post probably not impossible but unlikely. I've seen questions like this before regarding PC upgrades and PC not posting. Seems like CompTIA wants you to know that bios updates can make sure PC parts like the processor are compatible which is true. I would go with CPU support as the issue.
The system will still post without hard drives installed. So, that leaves only C.

The answer is correct cause wrong CPU generation wont fit on the motherboa
rd.

Selected Answer: C
C it is

Selected Answer: C
If there is no POST (Power on Selftest), than the CPU has a Problem or the Motherboard. But the Fans are working and there LEDs have Light, so it is probably not the Motherboard: It must be C (wrong CPU) !

Selected Answer: C
C. The wrong generation CPU is installed.

Selected Answer: C
I have faced the same situation with an incompatible CPU and the MB did not post fans just spun and that was that.
